title: Traumatic Diaphragmatic Rupture
diagnosis_topic: Left diaphragmatic tear from blunt trauma with herniation
setup_script: “A 45-year-old man presents after a high-speed motor vehicle collision with airbag deployment. He complains of left chest and abdominal pain. On arrival, he is alert but appears uncomfortable. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 125/80 mmHg, HR 100 bpm, RR 24/min, SpO₂ 93% on room air.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs primary survey and physical exam
dynamic_flow.reply: Decreased breath sounds on the left, bowel sounds audible in the chest, abdomen tender with guarding.
Elevated left hemidiaphragm with opacification; nasogastric tube seen coiling into chest.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident requests insertion of nasogastric tube
dynamic_flow.reply: It coils within the thoracic cavity, decompressing the stomach.
Herniation of stomach and splenic flexure into left hemithorax through a diaphragmatic defect.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays diagnosis or operative planning
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient develops worsening respiratory distress, hypoxia, and hemodynamic instability.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates resuscitation and prepares for OR
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient stabilizes with supplemental oxygen and fluids while awaiting surgery.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proceeds with operative management
dynamic_flow.reply: Laparotomy reveals a 6 cm left diaphragmatic tear with stomach and splenic flexure herniated into the chest.
Reduction of herniated contents, inspection for associated intra-abdominal injuries, primary repair of the diaphragm with non-absorbable sutures.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident is asked to describe operative technique
dynamic_flow.reply: Please describe your operative approach for reducing herniated viscera and repairing the diaphragmatic defect.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident assesses for associated injuries
dynamic_flow.reply: Splenic capsular tear noted but hemostatic; multiple left rib fractures present.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident neglects evaluation for associated injuries
dynamic_flow.reply: Splenic laceration with bleeding is missed, leading to postoperative hemorrhagic shock.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident completes operative repair and chest tube placement
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient is transferred to ICU, extubated on postoperative day 1, and recovers uneventfully.
Pulmonary toileting, chest tube care, pain control, and follow-up for recurrence.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident addresses mechanism of injury and prevention
dynamic_flow.reply: High-energy blunt trauma often causes diaphragmatic tears; proper seat belt use reduces risk.

critical_decision_points: Suspicion for diaphragmatic rupture in high-energy blunt trauma
Diagnostic interpretation of chest X-ray, nasogastric tube position, and CT scan
Timely surgical repair to prevent strangulation and respiratory compromise
Recognition and management of associated injuries (splenic, rib fractures)
Postoperative respiratory and critical care management
